articles.headline: Apple Strengthens Pull of Its Orbit With Each Device
articles.snippet: The tech giant has succeeded in ensuring that its phones, tablets and computers work seamlessly together. You might never leave.
articles.abstract: The tech giant has succeeded in ensuring that its phones, tablets and computers work seamlessly together. You might never leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late in 2012, when Tim Cook was relatively fresh on the job as Apple’s chief executive, he made a sudden and potentially risky shuffle in the firm’s executive ranks. He fired Scott Forstall, who had been in charge of Apple’s mobile operating system, the most important piece of software Apple produced. Mr. Forstall had long been one of Steve Jobs’s favored lieutenants, but in addition to presiding over a couple of prominent failures — including Apple’s Maps app — he was known for his combativeness within the company.

articles.headline: Blackwater Guards Found Guilty in 2007 Iraq Killings
articles.snippet: A federal jury found that the shooting deaths of 17 Iraqi civilians were not a battlefield tragedy, but the result of a criminal act.
articles.abstract: A federal jury found that the shooting deaths of 17 Iraqi civilians were not a battlefield tragedy, but the result of a criminal act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four former Blackwater Worldwide security guards were convicted and immediately jailed Wednesday for their roles in a deadly 2007 shooting in Baghdad’s Nisour Square that marked a bloody nadir in America’s war in Iraq.

articles.headline: Economists See Limited Gains in G.O.P. Plan
articles.snippet: Anticipating a takeover of Congress, Republicans have assembled an economic agenda that reflects their small-government philosophy, but leaves many economists underwhelmed.
articles.abstract: Anticipating a takeover of Congress, Republicans have assembled an economic agenda that reflects their small-government philosophy, but leaves many economists underwhelmed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anticipating a takeover of Congress, Republicans have assembled an economic agenda that reflects their small-government, antiregulation philosophy, but also suggests internal divisions that could hinder a united front against President Obama — much as happened in the 1990s, when a Republican-led Congress confronted President Bill Clinton.

articles.headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘1989’ Carries High Hopes
articles.snippet: The music industry eagerly awaits the first-week sales of Taylor Swift’s new album, “1989,” as CD sales continue to slump, and Ms. Swift moves farther away from country music.
articles.abstract: The music industry eagerly awaits the first-week sales of Taylor Swift’s new album, “1989,” as CD sales continue to slump, and Ms. Swift moves farther away from country music.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the few certainties in the music business these days is that if Taylor Swift puts out a new album, it will sell by the truckload.

articles.headline: More Boot Camp Than Spa
articles.snippet: Many established spas and retreats are retooling their offerings to attract the same target: wealthy, successful and highly stressed-out executives.
articles.abstract: Many established spas and retreats are retooling their offerings to attract the same target: wealthy, successful and highly stressed-out executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The irony did not escape Paula Thompson. As a regional vice president of a firm helping scores of companies administer wellness programs for their employees, the 58-year-old Ohio executive was not practicing what she preached. Years of job stress and a road-food diet left her out of shape, overweight and exhausted.

articles.headline: Years After the Market Collapse, Sidelined Borrowers Return
articles.snippet: The return of many of those who experienced foreclosures or short sales in the economic downturn could influence the housing market.
articles.abstract: The return of many of those who experienced foreclosures or short sales in the economic downturn could influence the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tracy S., 59, a technical writer for a large bank, divorced her husband just as the housing market spiraled downward. They were forced to sell their home, just outside Phoenix, for less than they owed, and the bank agreed to absorb the difference, about $25,000.

articles.headline: U.S. Loosens Reins, but Mortgage Lenders Want More Slack
articles.snippet: Financial regulators, trying to increase access to home loans, have relaxed many rules designed to prevent a repeat of the 2008 subprime crisis.
articles.abstract: Financial regulators, trying to increase access to home loans, have relaxed many rules designed to prevent a repeat of the 2008 subprime crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government, in recent days, has been giving one set of bankers nearly everything they want.

articles.headline: From a Rwandan Dump to the Halls of Harvard
articles.snippet: Justus Uwayesu’s life was changed by a chance encounter in Rwanda with an American charity worker.
articles.abstract: Justus Uwayesu’s life was changed by a chance encounter in Rwanda with an American charity worker.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Nine years old and orphaned by ethnic genocide, he was living in a burned-out car in a Rwandan garbage dump where he scavenged for food and clothes. Daytimes, he was a street beggar. He had not bathed in more than a year.

articles.headline: No Picket Fence: Younger Adults Opting to Rent
articles.snippet: Those in their 20s and 30s, who often cannot afford or do not want a mortgage, are looking for appealing rental housing, and developers are responding.
articles.abstract: Those in their 20s and 30s, who often cannot afford or do not want a mortgage, are looking for appealing rental housing, and developers are responding.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA, Va. — On a recent sunny afternoon, a half-dozen grinding and spinning cement trucks helped lay the foundation for what many real estate developers see as the most promising housing opportunity in postrecession America: apartment living.

articles.headline: Takata Airbag Recall Faces Rising Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Two senators demanded wider recalls and a House committee said it wanted a fuller accounting of how the recalls were handled.
articles.abstract: Two senators demanded wider recalls and a House committee said it wanted a fuller accounting of how the recalls were handled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capitol Hill increased pressure on the Japanese auto supplier Takata and federal safety regulators on Wednesday as two senators demanded wider recalls to fix millions of defective airbags and a House committee said it wanted a fuller accounting of how the recalls were handled.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: Taliban Are Rising Again in Afghanistan’s North
articles.snippet: Gains by militants in Kunduz Province put in doubt the ability of Afghan forces to hold territory just two months before the end of the 13-year international combat mission.
articles.abstract: Gains by militants in Kunduz Province put in doubt the ability of Afghan forces to hold territory just two months before the end of the 13-year international combat mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAHAR DARA, Afghanistan — The last time Afghans in the northern province of Kunduz felt so threatened by the Taliban was in 2009, just before President Obama deployed thousands of troops to push the insurgents back from the outskirts of the province’s capital.

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg, Speaking Mandarin, Tries to Win Over China for Facebook
articles.snippet: At a forum at Tsinghua University in Beijing, Facebook’s chief executive discussed his thoughts on the company’s future in the country and why he is studying Chinese.
articles.abstract: At a forum at Tsinghua University in Beijing, Facebook’s chief executive discussed his thoughts on the company’s future in the country and why he is studying Chinese.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook’s social network is almost completely blocked in China, but maybe Mark Zuckerberg hopes to charm his way past the government’s censors — by speaking to them in their own language.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel, Austin Ramzy and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Tesco Chairman to Step Down as Overstatement of Profit Grows
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Britain’s leading grocery store said that there was no timeline for Richard Broadbent’s exit and that an inquiry continued.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Britain’s leading grocery store said that there was no timeline for Richard Broadbent’s exit and that an inquiry continued.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — There was a time when Tesco, Britain’s largest grocery chain and the world’s third-largest retailer by sales, was a darling.

articles.headline: In West, ISIS Finds Women Eager to Enlist
articles.snippet: Analysts estimate that 10 percent of recruits from the West are women, often influenced by social media networks that offer advice, tips and logistical support for travel.
articles.abstract: Analysts estimate that 10 percent of recruits from the West are women, often influenced by social media networks that offer advice, tips and logistical support for travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The young Western Muslims trying to join radical Islamist groups in Syria and Iraq now include increasing numbers of young women who are seeking to fight or to become the wives of fighters. It is a new twist on a recruitment effort that has led several thousand men from Europe and beyond to flock to the battlefield.
